issues.title: sd_hash in issued CWT? issuer includes all possible disclosures?
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
currently the sd_hash claim in an SD-CWT is allowed when sent between an issuer and the holder. This is a claim which could not be verified by a verifier. I propose we remove it. If instead the Issuer is required to send salted claim disclosures for every digest in the payload (already proposed in PR #9 ), then the holder has another way of detecting tapering of the unprotected header. 

we also need confidentiality of the disclosures. the most common ways (ex: transport crypto, authenticated encryption of the entire SD-CWT) also provide additional integrity protection of the unprotected header between an issuer and a holder

issues.title: Can you have an SD-CWT with no blinded claims
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
is a zebra with no stripes still a zebra? 

likewise is it legal to have an SD-CWT with no blinded claims. shouldn't that just be a regular CWT?

It is easier to talk about what various roles have to do with this requirement. Is there a good reason to allow a CWT with `typ` "application/sd-cwt" that has no blinded claims?

Note that PR #9 currently assumes an SD-CWT needs at least one blinded claim.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: concluded. An SD-CWT can have zero blinded claims. Closing

comments.body: Lets do this before pushing -02

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: done. closing.

issues.title: Optional vs. mandatory claims?
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
The standard claims (iss, sub, iat, exp, nbf, etc.) in CBOR Web Token largely reference the semantics of the corresponding claims in JSON Web Token, which makes all the claims optional. Which of the standard claims do we want to make mandatory or optional?

## Summary of standard claims in SD-CWT and SD-KBT

### issuer (iss / 1)
This is currently mandatory in the SD-CWT and optional in the SD-KBT.

### subject (sub / 2)
Currently mandatory in the SD-CWT and optional in the SD-KBT. 

### audience (aud / 3)
Currently optional in the SD-CWT and mandatory in the SD-KBT. Use of an SD-CWT with no audience, or a different/less specific audience than the SD-KBT, is a requirement for use inside MLS credentials.

### expiration (exp / 4)
This is currently optional in the SD-CWT, but I think it should be mandatory in both.

### not-before (nbf / 5)
Current optional in both.

### issued-at (iat / 6)
Currently mandatory in both. I think this is fine, but we could potentially relax this to require either iat or cti

### cwt token id (cti / 7)
Currently optional. See comment above.  

### key confirmation (cnf / 8)
Mandatory in SD-CWT. Not present in SD-KBT.

### client nonce (cnonce / 39)
Currently mandatory in SD-KBT and optional in SD-CWT.

### disclosures-hash (sd_hash / TBD3)
Currently mandatory in both. Recommend removing from SD-CWT as discussed in issue #10

### disclosures hash algorithm (sd_alg / TBD4)
Mandatory in SD-CWT. Not present in SD-KBT.

## Proposed changes
 - Add expiration (exp / 4) as mandatory in SD-CWT
 - Remove sd_hash from SD-CWT as discussed in #10

issues.title: Using "keys" in claim names for non-cryptographic keys is potentially confusing
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
Hi, Mike Jones pointed out that SD-CWT is using "keys" in claim names (ex: `redacted_keys`) in a way which is potentially confusing. We refer to cryptographic keys (ex: confirmation key—`cnf`) and CBOR map keys throughout the document.

The proposal is to rename `redacted_keys` to something else which makes it clear that it is a "map key" and not a cryptographic key. `redacted_elements` or `redacted_values` imply that only the values (and not the claim names) are included.

I propose:

`redacted_map_claims`

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
This naming needs to be consistent for arrays and maps.

- redacted_map_claims
- redacted_array_claim 

?

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> This naming needs to be consistent for arrays and maps.
> 
>     * redacted_map_claims
>     * redacted_array_claim

I'm not sure. The first is an array of claims that are each items in a map at the same level, and will have an integer key. The second is the map key of a single-element map which represents one item inside an array, and might be represented by the text strong "...".  

This still might be the best suggestion (or least bad). Let's see.

comments.author: mprorock
comments.body:
what about:
redacted_claim_XXX <- XXX replaced appropriated
?

comments.body:
Mike Prorock asked:
>what about:
>redacted_claim_XXX <- XXX replaced appropriated

Mike, do you mean this?
redacted_claim_map_key
redacted_claim_array_item

Thanks,
-rohan

issues.title: renaming "sd_claims"
issues.author: beltram
issues.body:
Currently, disclosed claims, represented in the CDDL by a `salted_array` have the same name (`sd_claims`) and the same key (`TBD1`), regardless if they are in the issued token or the presented one.

First of all, in each case they carry different semantics: they are "potentially disclosable" in the `sd-cwt-issued` whereas they are actually "actually disclosed" in the `sd-cwt-presentation`. So I think they should have at least a different name. Since we're not using JSON we do not have to abbreviate our keys so I would go for a full name.

Then, they both have structural differences. If we add Decoys as suggested in #11 , the `sd_claims` issued supports them whereas the presented one must not. I think it will help down the road help implementation of the spec easier by "making illegal state unrepresentable".

I think it could look like this: 
```cddl
salted-issued = salted-claim / salted-element / decoy
salted-presentation = salted-claim / salted-element

salted-array-issued = [ +bstr .cbor salted-issued ]
salted-array-presentation = [ +bstr .cbor salted-presentation ]

unprotected-issued = {
   &(disclosures-issued: TBD_X) ^ => bstr .cbor salted-array-issued,
}

unprotected-presentation = {
   ? &(disclosures-presentation: TBD_Y) ^ => bstr .cbor salted-array-presentation,
}
```

What do you think ? I'll be happy to contribute to that in a PR.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
Can we use "mandatory to disclose" and "optional to disclose" for the issuer cwt claims.

and "presented claims" and "optional to present claims" for the presented kbt including the issuer signed cwt?

comments.author: beltram
comments.body:
Sorry for missing your reply. Actually this aged poorly wrt to the recent draft changes 😅 

Since KBT now wraps the SD-CWT no need anymore for 2 different keys for the disclosures.

Also, regarding Decoys, I think that now that we have sunset `sd_hash` there's no reason for them to be present in the disclosures since the Holder does not have to verify their integrity ; that's [exactly what SD-JWT does](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-oauth-selective-disclosure-jwt-14#section-4.2.5-3).
So no need for 2 flavors of `salted-array` anymore.

I'm not sure I get your comment right: that'd mean an issuer could mandate a holder to do a presentation of the claims in "mandatory to disclose" ? In that case why redacting those ?
Feel free to reopen if I missed something 😄

issues.title: privacy considerations should include linkability or unlinkability, and the associated use cases
issues.author: npdoty
issues.body:
Privacy considerations are currently missing from this draft, but could use some extensive documentation.

But most urgently, the draft should be clear about whether selective disclosure also reveals linkability across different verifiers, or not. What is revealed about the issuer is also a separate disclosure, as well as a potential source of linkability. It sounds like there might be some significant use cases where linkability and selective disclosure is desirable, though age verification might not be one like that.

For many use cases, particularly on the web, linkability across verifiers (or between colluding verifier and issuer) is a particular privacy concern and unlinkability is a desirable property. The draft should make it clear which properties are provided.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
The privacy considerations for sd-cwt are very similar to that of sd-jwt, @npdoty do you think we should use a reference, or would you like us to propose alternative framing of these considerations?

If you have a chance to review the sd-jwt considerations, I welcome any comments on where we should add more or less text.

Hope to see you in person at a future IETF.

comments.author: Denisthemalice
comments.body:
I raised several issues during the last call from SD-JWT.

(# 514) A section should be added to consider the case of a presentation of claims to Verifier that have been issued by different Issuers (https://github.com/oauth-wg/oauth-selective-disclosure-jwt/issues/514)

I sent an update of this issue:
(# 529) Update of Issue #514 (new section 9.12) for the support of Post Quantum cryptography 
(https://github.com/oauth-wg/oauth-selective-disclosure-jwt/pull/529)

(# 515) The term "unlinkability" is overloaded. For more clarity, the wording "End-user intrackability" should be used in addition
(https://github.com/oauth-wg/oauth-selective-disclosure-jwt/issues/515)

(# 516) A new section about "End-User intrackability" should be added
(https://github.com/oauth-wg/oauth-selective-disclosure-jwt/issues/516)

These contributions can be used to fill-in the Privacy Considerations section.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: I think we are ready to tackle this, I wonder if we should mirror the considerations from sd-jwt, or is there is some utility in presenting the considerations differently.

comments.author: Denisthemalice
comments.body: I would answer slightly differently. Indications should be given about the fact that the revocation/ suspension mechanism can prevent to support the verifier-verifier unlinkability property, like the use of Token Status Lists. See a post on this topic: https://github.com/oauth-wg/draft-ietf-oauth-status-list/issues/207

comments.author: Denisthemalice
comments.body:
In  SD-JWT an issue 516 has  been raised but immediately closed preventing any discussion on it.
 It was proposing to add a new section called "End-User intrackability" 
(https://github.com/oauth-wg/oauth-selective-disclosure-jwt/issues/516)

This wording might be used but I recently found another possible wording "Unobservability".

It is present in a paper called "Architecture Proposal for the German eIDAS Implementation"
https://gitlab.opencode.de/bmi/eudi-wallet/eidas-2.0-architekturkonzept/-/blob/main/architecture-proposal.md

The wording "Unobservability" is used in it . It is defined as follows:

> 
> **Unobservability**
> Unobservability refers to the property where an adversary cannot discern any useful information about a communication or transaction. This ensures that sensitive data, such as message content, sender or receiver identity, or any other relevant information, remains hidden from unauthorized parties. In this context, **neither Wallet Providers nor Issuers shall be able to track** where a user uses their credentials or learn details concerning the attributes provided.

It is important of not overloading the meaning of the word unlinkability, as it is currently the case in SD-JWT, and avoid the use of terms that are too long and not easily understandable :

```
Issuer/Verifier Unlinkability (Honest Verifier): 
Issuer/Verifier Unlinkability (Colluding/Compromised Verifier)
```

issues.title: Register application/sd-cwt+cwt and application/sd-kbt+cwt in CoAP Content Formats registry?
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
The COSE `typ` header can specify either a text string media format, or a uint16 from the [CoAP Content Formats Registry](https://www.iana.org/assignments/core-parameters/core-parameters.xhtml#content-formats). Do we want to pre-emptively register SD-CWT and SD-KBT media types in the IETF Review range (256-9999) [1] so they can be referred to in COSE by integer?

[1] see Table 10 in [RFC7252, Section 12.3](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7252.html#section-12.3)

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: Discussed on our call, work in progress.

pulls.title: small fix to the CDDL
pulls.author: rohanmahy
pulls.body:
fix to full cddl and one instance of the same CDDL in the body of the draft

CDDL was not happy with:

```
? &(sd_claims: TBD1) ^ => [ +bstr .cbor salted ]
```

, so I replaced with:

```
? &(sd_claims: TBD1) ^ => bstr .cbor salted-array,
```

where `salted-array` is `salted-array = [ +bstr .cbor salted ]`

pulls.title: Make Abstract conform to IETF-required style
pulls.author: rohanmahy
pulls.body:
According to https://authors.ietf.org/required-content (Abstract section), the Abstract of an I-D or RFC needs to stand alone. It should not contain abbreviations or references.

Changes:
- Removed references from Abstract
- Expanded abbreviations in Abstract
- Added Updates: RFC8392 to metadata
- Introduced first references in Introduction
-

```suggestion
consists of standard CWT claims, the holder confirmation key, and five specific
custom claims. The payload is shown below in CBOR Extended Diagnostic
Notation (EDN) {{!I-D.ietf-cbor-edn-literals}}. Note that some of the CWT claim
```


```suggestion
```

I don't think that including a hex CBOR representation enhances the readers' comprehension of the text.  The CDDL above does the job fine by itself.  I'd delete the hex CBOR.

pulls.title: Reoganize and partially rewrite the main normative sections
pulls.author: rohanmahy

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
sent to spice mailing list:
"A made three small technical changes, for which I will create issues after I take a break.

1) The text in this PR says that the Issuer has to send the Salted Disclosed Claims for every digest in an SD-CWT. If not the Issuer could issue claims that the Holder can never verify that could be embarrassing or false (like "Alice still likes the boy band of her youth", or "Rohan thinks the earth is flat"). (Update: Issue #10 )
2) I questioned if a CWT with no blinded claims can be an SD-CWT. My conclusion was no, so I changed the cardinality to at least 1 blinded claim. Of course you can disclose between zero and all of them. (Update: Issue #12 )
3) I left a hook to allow us to trivially add Decoy Digests (Update: Issue #11 )

I can change any of these things. Changing 1 and 3 are pretty trivial, and Changing 2 is still straightforward."

comments.body:
```suggestion
in CBOR and COSE. An SD-CWT MUST include the protected header parameter
`typ` {RFC9596} with the value `application/sd-cwt` in the SD-CWT.
```
"dict" isn't a CBOR or COSE term.

```suggestion
The Issuer MUST implement COSE_Sign1 using an appropriate asymmetric
```

```suggestion
The Issuer MUST generate a unique cryptographically random salt with at least
```
Why is "exp" optional?  It seems like it should be required.

I would change all instances of "redacted_keys" to "redacted_values".  It is unfortunate that CBOR chose to use the term "key" for the labels of objects, as it inevitably causes readers confusion between cryptographic keys and object keys.

Please let's reserve the term "key" for cryptographic keys.
I would suggest saying what about the unprotected header is different.  Help readers understand without having to look elsewhere in the spec.

RFC8392 is silent about if exp is required in a CWT. It refers to the definition in [Section 4.1.4 of RFC7519](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7519#section-4.1.4) which says `exp` is optional in a JWT.

```suggestion
SD-CWT to the Holder.) An SD-KBT is itself a type of CWT. The protected header of the SD-KBT
MUST include the `typ` header parameter with the value `application/sd-kbt`.
```

```suggestion
Profiles built on this specification are also encouraged to use more specific media types, as described in {{?RFC9596}}.
```

For what it's worth, *all* claims are optional in JWTs because they are expected to be profiled for particular use cases.  In our case, we may want to define the minimum required claims.

I thought that the "?" syntax above made "exp" optional.  Am I correct?  And similarly, the change above makes "aud" optional.  Is that what we want to do?

> 

```suggestion
in CBOR and COSE. An SD-CWT MUST include the protected header parameter
`typ` {{!RFC9596}} with the value "application/sd-cwt" in the SD-CWT.
```

```suggestion
replaced with a CBOR map containing only the special key "...".
```

> 

```suggestion
payload. The payload MUST also include a key confirmation element (`cnf`) {{!RFC8747}}
```

I have a legitimate use case for "aud" to be optional (use in MLS), but the "aud" would be required in the Key Binding Token.

For "exp" I cannot think of a use case where we want a never expiring SD-CWT, but I was hesitant to change the optionality and break someone else's use case.

> I would change all instances of "redacted_keys" to "redacted_values". It is unfortunate that CBOR chose to use the term "key" for the labels of objects, as it inevitably causes readers confusion between cryptographic keys and object keys.
> 
> Please let's reserve the term "key" for cryptographic keys.

"values" doesn't convey the difference between array items map elements. keys isn't really correct either.  How do folks feel about `redacted_elements`?

> 

```suggestion
Profiles built on this specification are also encouraged to use more specific media
types, as described in {{!RFC9596}}.
```
I meant `nbf` and `exp`. The current time is greater or equal to `nbf` and not more than `exp`. What comparison would you make with `iat`?
I'll take a stab at this tomorrow.
fixed

```suggestion
same syntax as an SD-CWT issued to a Holder, except for its unprotected header.
Since the unprotected header is not included in the signature, it will contain
all the Salted Disclosed Claims when sent from the Issuer to the Holder. By
comparison, the unprotected header will include a Key Binding Token and contain
none, some, or all of these Claims when sent from the Holder to the Verifier.
```

> I'll take a stab at this tomorrow.

How well does the proposed change (starting line 329) address your concern about explaining the unprotected header?
I created Issue #14 for this. I propose we resolve in this PR and incorporate the result of this conclusion in another PR.
I proposed `redacted_map_claims` in Issue #15 . Let's please merge this PR while these other issues get discussed.
Marking as resolved, to be addressed in Issue #14
Marking resolved. Captured in Issue #15

pulls.title: Add Brian to Acknowledgments
pulls.author: rohanmahy

pulls.title: turn the cnonce in the kbt optional
pulls.author: beltram
pulls.body:
Hi,

this fixes a small inconsistency in the draft since it is stated at the beginning of the draft that `To protect against replay attacks, the verifier SHOULD provide a nonce, and reject requests that do not include an acceptable an nonce (cnonce). This guidance can be ignored in cases where replay attacks are mitigated at another layer`.

There are two options here: either turn the claim optional or have the Holder use a fixed nonce in case he did not get one from the Verifier. I prefer the former. 

Thoughts ?

comments.body:
```suggestion
The Holder MAY fetch a nonce from the Verifier to prevent replay, or obtain a nonce acceptable to the verifier through a process similar to the one described in draft-ietf-httpbis-unprompted-auth-12.
```
We might also consider a reference to the nonce endpoint as described here: https://github.com/openid/OpenID4VCI/pull/381/files

I wonder, since this is related to VC, if it shouldn't go in a "profile" document (for VC in this case). Regarding nonces we could however add a section in the "Security Considerations" and incorporate sane recommendations (size, expiry, reuse etc..) by inspiring us from this draft

I consider nonce management part of safely executing cnf, which is a layer above profiles that need confirmation... But you are right that many app protocol flows will probably need to support nonces in order to support the protocol.

pulls.title: Addressing a few issues
pulls.author: OR13
pulls.body:
- https://github.com/ietf-wg-spice/draft-ietf-spice-sd-cwt/issues/15
- https://github.com/ietf-wg-spice/draft-ietf-spice-sd-cwt/issues/14
- https://github.com/ietf-wg-spice/draft-ietf-spice-sd-cwt/issues/13
- https://github.com/ietf-wg-spice/draft-ietf-spice-sd-cwt/issues/12

I also did a bunch of editorial work, addressing some TDBs and making all sentences start on new lines.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: What's the reason for changing the registry values from TBD<n> to concrete integers that will probably change?

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: Consistency, we could go the other way and use TBDs in the examples and only list the number in the requested assignments.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
We discussed the following references related to this:

- https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9277.html#appendix-B
- https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8392#section-3
- https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8392#section-9.1.1
- https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8392#section-1.1

```suggestion
Selective Disclosure CBOR Web Tokens (SD-CWTs) are CWTs and can be deployed in protocols that are already using CWTs, even if they contain no optional to disclose claims.
```

reviews.author: rohanmahy
reviews.body: I think the new formulation of redacted_claim_element is extremely problematic and needs to be rolled back.

comments.body:
```suggestion
SD-CWT enables Issuers to mark certain Claim Keys or Claim Values mandatory or optional for a holder of a CWT to disclose.
```

```suggestion
This specification enables Holders of CWT based credentials to prove the integrity and authenticity of selected attributes asserted by an Issuer about a Subject to a Verifier.
```
What is this sentence trying to accomplish? To anyone familiar with CBOR this is a extraneous. To anyone just trying to follow this conceptually this is going to be confusing.

```suggestion
: The CBOR map containing zero or more Redacted Claim Keys or Redacted Claim Elements.
```

```suggestion
: The CBOR map containing all mandatory to disclose claims signed by the issuer, all selectively disclosed claims presented by the holder, and ommiting all undisclosed instances of Redacted Claim Keys and Redacted Claim Element claims that are present in the original SD-CWT.
```

This doesn't work. There is a reasonable chance that some array out in the world will have an array element which takes a map of an integer to something and already uses the integer key value 14. The "..." is weird and ugly because it is supposed to be so weird and so ugly that nobody in their right mind is using a map with a key of "...".

```suggestion
The digest value is included in the payload in a `redacted_claim_keys` field for a Redacted Claim Key (in this example), or in a named array for a Redacted Claim Element (ex: for a redacted claim element of `swversion`).
```

```suggestion
This claim is defined for COSE based verifiable credentials, similar to the JOSE based verifiable credentials claim (`vct`) described in Section 3.2.2.1.1 of {{-SD-JWT-VC}}.
```
I don't think this is going to work as I described above.

This "Claim" terminology is specific to CWT, not CBOR.

The intention was to address part of Mike's comment about map keys and cryptographic  keys being confusing, I'm repeating the CWT terminology here to try to address that, although I am more than happy to remove this text if we can avoid it.
Yep, I agree... We're discussing this on CBOR and SPICE lists currently.
I think my intention was to relate the registration requests... This should probably just be removed.
I was referring to ", which are expressed using the Major Types described in {{RFC8949}}." Can we please just nuke that?

```suggestion
CWT Claims Sets contain Claim Keys and Claim Values.
```
We should merge as is, and revisit after list discussion
I am fine with removing
we're gonna have keep processing this, here: https://github.com/ietf-wg-spice/draft-ietf-spice-sd-cwt/issues/19
same issue https://github.com/ietf-wg-spice/draft-ietf-spice-sd-cwt/issues/19

pulls.title: Reduce chance of collisions
pulls.author: OR13

pulls.title: Add author
pulls.author: OR13

pulls.title: Use CBOR tag for redacted (array) claim elements
pulls.author: rohanmahy
pulls.body:
- Replace older redacted (array) claim element forms `{"...", h'1234abcd'}` and `{ / redacted_claim_element / 65555: h'1234abcd'}` with a CBOR tagged digest: `60(h'1234abcd')`
- Register the CBOR tag to indicate a redacted claim element
- Consistently use the names `redacted_claim_elements` and `redacted_claim_keys`
- Replace 65556 with -65536 to be a shorter to represent, and possibly rarer number to encounter as a map key (note that this syntax may be replaced in a future PR)
- Make the appropriate changes consistently in the examples and in the CDDL file
- Register a different CBOR tag to indicate the intent to redact a claim (key, or element)
- Fix the formatting of the IANA registration section

comments.body: this should probably make it clear that its requested assignment.

```suggestion
* Tag: TBD9 (requested assignment 60)
```

```suggestion
* Tag: TBD10 (requested assignment 58)
```
We should make this the SPICE WG list.

```suggestion
When blinding an individual item in an array, the value of the item is replaced with the digested salted hash as a CBOR binary string, wrapped with a CBOR tag (requested tag number 60).
```

While I think that is generally a good idea, most RFCs (even standards track ones, and even recent ones such as RFC9431) are using a person's name and email address. Is there a document that says we should use WG mailing lists now?  If so, I am happy to change it.
Created an [issue](https://github.com/ietf-wg-mediaman/6838bis/issues/9) on [draft-mediaman-6838bis](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-mediaman-6838bis/)

For this stuff, I recommend something like this:

```
Claim Name:
: redacted_claim_keys

Claim Description:
...

Specification Document(s):
: RFC XXXX
{: spacing="compact"}
```

Recent documents that I've gotten through publication look like this:

```
   Person and email address to contact for further information:
      See Authors' Addresses section
```

Separately, please see the source of RFC 9458 for a better media type registration template:  https://github.com/ietf-wg-ohai/oblivious-http/blob/main/draft-ietf-ohai-ohttp.md

Thanks. with compact and bold added, this is certainly better, but when we get to the Additional information: field with 3 subfields, that syntax just doesn't know how to handle it.  It is also way too verbose in the source. I'll stick with the bullet items for this document, but use the compact definition rendering (with bold) in future docs that don't have multiple indent levels.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
There is a proposal to use simple values instead of tags: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/spice/1qHebZZ1rxS7QvDao9ENYswbiU0/

unfortunately it appears that simple values are not well supported in CBOR tooling, for at least the rust language.

I suggest we proceed with the tag approach and upgrade to simple values if the tooling situation improves.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: Merging. If we see strong library support for a new simple type, we can introduce a very short PR to change it.

pulls.title: I-D text changes, CDDL, and example use construction described by Daniel Fett
pulls.author: rohanmahy
pulls.body:
Created a CDDL and example (in EDN) of the construction described by Daniel Fett, and made the draft consistent with that construction.

the KBT payload contains the a claim (called here issuer_sd_cwt) which is an embedded bstr of the entire Issuer SD-CWT. The unprotected header of the issued-cwt has zero or more disclosures.

I also moved sd_alg into the issuer SD-CWT protected header.

This construction dramatically simplified the CDDL schema. The example is a bit harder to read, merely because the issuer SD-CWT is more deeply nested. Overall this construction is simpler and requires fewer new claims.

pulls.title: Make Document History section up to date
pulls.author: rohanmahy

pulls.title: Rohan's issues ready for PR
pulls.author: rohanmahy

comments.body:
Is this true? wouldn't this yield:

```
"_sd": [],
```

which is a commitment to zero disclosures at this level of the map?
I do not know if we need `iss` to be mandatory, especially if SD-CWT is signed with x5t /x5u, where the issue is represented using a cert.

its weird that all other claims are optional, but iss and sub are MUST NOT.

the important part is the KBT is signed by key identified in cnf... other things the holder wants to sign are probably use case / protocol specific, and we may want to leave room for them.
yes

The point is that the issuer and the subject are the party represented by the cnf (and possibly given an identifier in the sub) in the issued SD-CWT. I want to tell implementers that there is no value sending iss or sub in the KBT so they don't need to waste time writing code checking if they exist and then comparing them to whatever their canonical representation is of the the party in the cnf. Since sub is redactable in the CWT, the language to describe matching rules for iss and sub in the KBT would be super complicated and confusing. (All to manage a possibility that adds zero functionality).

I think we owe it to the community to tell people NO in this case.

An SD-CWT does not need to have any disclosable claims present in its payload, or any arrays or maps inside the payload.

When an SD-CWT has no disclosable claims, the redacted map key and redacted array element MUST NOT be present anywhere in the payload.
Move this maybe to a better spot?
The issuer `iss` / 1 standard claim SHOULD be present, unless the protected header contains a certificate or certificate-like entity which fully identifies the issuer.

The holder is the issuer of the key binding token.

However, the iss and sub claims are optional in the key binding token.

- put this somewhere:
    "The Holder is conceptually both the subject and the issuer of the Key Binding Token."

- remove the MUST NOT

- in verification section:
      ignore iss or sub for validation purposes (if present). A profile may define additional semantics.

- in security considerations
     warn about attack of issuer or subject in KBT not matching each other or the subject in the SD-CWT (any self-assigned identifier)
The Holder is conceptually ... the issuer and subject of the kbt
The iss is issuer signed CWT is self asserted by the issuer. the iss and sub in KBT are self asserted by the holder.

@OR13 @mprorock @henkbirkholz
I just want to make sure that we still want the extra bstr encoding of each disclosure: 
`<<[salt, key, value]>>` vs `[salt, key, value]`. I don't have a strong objection, but I don't see the value in the extra encoding/decoding step (or the extra 2 or 3 bytes). The bstr encoding doesn't prevent the inside value from being non-deterministically encoded, for example. That canonicalization needs to happen when encoding the disclosure array anyway.

We should be able to justify in text why we add double CBOR encoding anywhere.

I just pushed https://github.com/ietf-wg-spice/draft-ietf-spice-sd-cwt/pull/36/commits/233a4fb04eac5352eb2b9cf59f9f8ff6e224e860 which I addresses all these concerns. I would appreciate a look @OR13 at the language in the security considerations section.
I didn't move this, but I think it is much nicer now as of https://github.com/ietf-wg-spice/draft-ietf-spice-sd-cwt/pull/36/commits/b7eb6904a8e71320a7a2d15b944a5c0670c9bdb8

Yeah, I could be convinced on this.

My reasoning is similar to the feeling of processing COSE headers.

I decode a cose-sign1, and the protected header is ready to use as bytes, for example as aead aad.

Then if / when I need parameters inside I decode the protected header.

In our case, we need to compute hashes on these disclosures right away, so if they decode as arrays, then will need to be re-encoded to produce the hashes.

We maybe don't need the outer encoding now that we don't had sd_hash in kbt... so instead of:

```
/ sd_claims / 17 : /just the disclosures chosen by the Holder/
<<[
    <<[
        /salt/   h'8d5c15fa86265d8ff77a0e92720ca837',
        /claim/  501,  / inspector_license_number /
        /value/  "ABCD-123456"
    ]>>,
    <<[
        /salt/   h'86c84b9c3614ba27073c7e5a475a2a13',
        /value/  1549560720  / inspected 7-Feb-2019 /
    ]>>,
    <<[
        /salt/   h'30eef86edeaa197df7bd3d17dd89cd87',
        /claim/  "region",
        /value/  "ca" /California/
    ]>>
]>>
```

We would have:

```
/ sd_claims / 17 : / just the disclosures chosen by the Holder /
[
    <<[
        /salt/   h'8d5c15fa86265d8ff77a0e92720ca837',
        /claim/  501,  / inspector_license_number /
        /value/  "ABCD-123456"
    ]>>,
    <<[
        /salt/   h'86c84b9c3614ba27073c7e5a475a2a13',
        /value/  1549560720  / inspected 7-Feb-2019 /
    ]>>,
    <<[
        /salt/   h'30eef86edeaa197df7bd3d17dd89cd87',
        /claim/  "region",
        /value/  "ca" /California/
    ]>>
]
```

I do think the first step of processing should be:

sd_claims .map sd_hash_alg
reduce decode sd_claim, so you end with the disclosures by hash value map, and are ready to begin processing the verified payload.

This is actually unique to SD-CWT because key binding is mandatory.
We should probably say much more about this.

Perhaps:

Because confirmation is mandatory, the subject claim of an SD-CWT, when present, is always related directly to the confirmation claim.

There might be many subject claims and many confirmation keys that identify the same entity or that are controlled by the same entity, while the identifiers and keys are distinct values.

Reusing an identifier or key enables traceability, but MUST be evaluated in terms of the confidential and privacy constraints associated with the credential type.

These are a good start, but we should probably tighten this a bit further.
I don't have enough caffeine to help yet.

```suggestion
Because confirmation is mandatory, the subject claim of an SD-CWT, when present, is always related directly to the confirmation claim.

There might be many subject claims and many confirmation keys that identify the same entity or that are controlled by the same entity, while the identifiers and keys are distinct values.

Reusing an identifier or key enables traceability, but MUST be evaluated in terms of the confidential and privacy constraints associated with the credential type.
```

```suggestion

Because confirmation is mandatory, the subject claim of an SD-CWT, when present, is always related directly to the confirmation claim.
There might be many subject claims and many confirmation keys that identify the same entity or that are controlled by the same entity, while the identifiers and keys are distinct values.
Reusing an identifier or key enables traceability, but MUST be evaluated in terms of the confidential and privacy constraints associated with the credential type.
```

pulls.title: Add some initial text regarding security considerations
pulls.author: OR13

comments.body:
```suggestion
Issuers choose which claims to include in an SD-CWT, and whether they are mandatory to disclose, including self asserted claims such as "iss".
```

when you wrote "missued" did you mean:
issued?
misissued?
something else?

If misissued, I would use "incorrectly issued"
unclear what the word "set" means here. Is it a verb, or is it a noun "low anonymity set"? Either way there is probably a clearer way to say this.

```suggestion
Issuers MUST perform a privacy and confidentiality assessment regarding each credential type they intend to issue prior to issuance.
```
Maybe worth paraphrasing these concepts in a couple of paragraphs? (I'm ok if this is a separate issue and is added later as another PR).

```suggestion
Does the credential type contain Personally Identifiable Information (PII), or other sensitive information which might have value in a market.
```

Line 762 is incorrect. 

Issuers cannot do this. They should only do this for the credential types that are mandatory to be disclosed. 

Change into:

> For each credential type that will be mandatorily diclosed, prior to issuance, Issuers MUST perform a privacy and confidentiality assessment.

@Denisthemalice I think you are confusing "credential type" (a profile with guidance about specific claims), and a claim. 

Credential types aren't disclosed, claims are.

I would be open to that.
I was hoping to get some help from Nick Doty on how to frame this topic.

```suggestion
Certificate transparency as described in {{-CT}}, or key transparency as described in {{-KT}} can enable the observation of incorrectly issued certificates or fraudulent bindings between verification keys and issuer identifiers.
```

```suggestion
Any claim value with sufficiently low "anonymity set" can be used track the subject.
```
probably this is best addressed by writing some paragraphs about t-closeness

pulls.title: Attempt to add text addressing CDE
pulls.author: OR13
pulls.body:
This pull requests comments on the use of CDE in the security considerations section.

This PR addresses: https://github.com/ietf-wg-spice/draft-ietf-spice-sd-cwt/issues/23

comments.body:
COSE has rules for the bstrs used, but not the contents inside the encoded bstr!

```suggestion
{{Section 9 of !RFC9052}} already requires the top-level structure of CWTs to be in a simple deterministic encoding.
It is possible to encode additional information through the choices made during the serialization stage of producing an SD-CWT claimset, for example, by adjusting the order of CBOR map keys, or by choosing different numeric encodings for certain data elements before the payload is bstr encoded. {{-CDE}} provides guidance for constructing application profiles that constrain serialization optionality beyond CBOR Common Deterministic Encoding Profile (CDE). The construction of such profiles has a significant impact on the privacy properties of a credential type.
```
